page.title: 01The Comb,History and Forest
page.content: The Comb, now 2 cottages (one holiday) and a separate out-door Centre Hotel, was built in 1800 but the remains of the old bastle can still be seen in the field opposite and behind are the pens for the cattle on the old drove road from Scotland to England. To the south, west and north lies the forests, to the east the remaining farm land extending south down the road though Shipley Sheils, Gleedlee and Gatehouse Bastle remain at Shipley and Gatehouse. In the forest on the west side of the Tarset Burn are are the bastles of Corbit Jack and Barty, both in ruins. The best land is used for hay and other times with rest used for suckling catle and sheep. Roe Deer ae common in the Forest and on occasions graze in the fields.
